text.en: During the last challenge, you learned how speed is generated by using different sizes of gears. Now, let's study how to use gears to slow down.
For this challenge you will need the same model that we used during the previous challenge.
Review: We already know that using two gears of the same size don't change the speed of one another.
Review: We have also learned that the bigger the driver gear is, the faster the driven gear will rotate.
Let's see what happens when we have a small driver gear with a larger driven gear. First, let's use a 40-tooth-gear as the driven gear and a 20-tooth-gear as the driver gear.

If the driver gear is half the size of the driven gear, it will slow it down by 50%. In other words, with one complete turn of the handle, our wheel will only rotate half way around.
20/40=0.5
0.5x40=20
Now let's use a 60-tooth-gear as a driven gear with a 20-tooth-gear driver gear to move the wheel even slower. How many rounds does the wheel turn with one spin of the handle?

If the driver gear has three times fewer gears than the driven gear, it will slow its speed down by three times. Our wheel will rotate a 0.33 circles with one spin of a handle.
20/60=0.33
0.33x60=20
How many rounds does the wheel rotate if we attach a 40-tooth-gear (driver gear) to a 60-tooth-gear (driven gear)?

The wheel rotates 0.66 rounds with one spin of the handle.
40/60=0.66
0.66x60=40
